statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

article.description: Smith scored 13 of his career-high 20 points in the fourth quarter to lift the surging Spurs to an 86-76 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers, who have not won here in nearly 16 years.
article.headline: Deep reserve Smith decodes Sixers' defense

images.name: Duncan, Tim 011207 inline
images.caption: Tim Duncan hit only five of 14 shots against Dikembe Mutombo's defense, but finished with 18 points and nine rebounds.

article.linkText: Smith cracks Sixers' defense with four 3's; Spurs win
article.story:
SAN ANTONIO (AP) -- Reserve guard Charles Smith has figured out that the best way to get minutes is to put on a show. Smith made three 3-pointers during a critical stretch of the fourth quarter Friday night to lead the San Antonio Spurs to an 86-76 victory over the depleted Philadelphia 76ers. Smith, who had appeared in only five of the Spurs' first 17 games, finished with a career-high 20 points to lead all scorers. Tim Duncan added 18 points and nine rebounds, while David Robinson and Antonio Daniels each had 12 points. "I always felt like I could compete -- I just needed to stay aggressive," said Smith, who shot 7-for-10 from the floor, including four 3-pointers. "It felt good to go out and execute tonight." The 76ers played without guard Allen Iverson and forward Derrick Coleman, who together average 44 points a game. Iverson has a sprained thumb, while Coleman was a last-minute scratch due to a hyperextended left knee. Philadelphia, playing its third game in four nights, kept pace with San Antonio for most of the game, tying the score at 63 on a driving layup by Raja Bell with 9:26 remaining. Smith then hit three 25-footers and had a blocked shot in less than two minutes as the Spurs built a 74-65 lead. After a tip-in by Corie Blount with 6:47 left, the 76ers didn't score another field goal for more than four minutes. Spurs coach Gregg Popovich said both teams did what they wanted to do on defense. "For anyone who likes defense, which is zero fans, this was a great game," he said. "One guy broke it for us and that was Charles Smith. If not for him, we would have been here all night." Speedy Claxton, starting in place of Iverson, led Philadelphia with 19 points. Dikembe Mutombo contributed 14 points and 10 rebounds, and Matt Harpring added 14 points. 76er coach Larry Brown said his team came away with a moral victory, if nothing else. "As short-handed as we are, to perform like that against a great team, I'm proud of them," he said. "I felt like we won." With their two top scorers sidelined, the 76ers came out with an offense that relied on long-range shooting by Claxton and Harpring, while at the other end they tried to harass the Spurs with a scrambling man-to-man defense. San Antonio led for most of the first quarter, but back-to-back 3-pointers by Aaron McKie and Vonteego Cummings and a driving layup by McKie gave Philadelphia a 28-24 lead early in the second. Smith responded with his first 3-pointer of the night, and a pair of free throws by Duncan started a 16-4 run that gave the Spurs their largest lead of the half at 40-32 with 3:49 remaining. Mutombo and Claxton each made two baskets to pull the 76ers within three, 43-40, at the break.

Game notes
At 14-4, the Spurs are off to their best start ever. ... Robinson was one rebound short of recording his fifth double-double in the past six games. He had no double-doubles in his first 11 games of the season. ... The loss was the 76ers' 15th straight in San Antonio, dating back to January 1986. It is Philadelphia's longest active road losing streak. ... Philly had only two turnovers in the first half, but eight in the second half.
